petitioner.name:
PACIFIC OPERATORS OFFSHORE,
LLP, ET AL.

respondent.name: v. LUISA L. VALLADOLID, ET AL

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We'll hear argument first this morning in Case 10-507, Pacific Operators Offshore v. Valladolid. Mr. Clement.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: When you say on land, do you -- where do you put the 3-mile State offshore limit?  Does that count as land under your view?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Mr. Clement, just to follow up on the Chief Justice's question, if there's a helicopter crash in the water, let's say it occurs 2.5 miles from the shore, is that covered?  And, similarly, would it be covered if it occurred 3.5 miles from the shore?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: The curious thing about this case is that the statutory language seems to me to speak quite clearly to some theory of causation.  Any injury occurring as the result of operations conducted on the outer continental shelf.  That's -- that's causation. Maybe it's but-for, maybe it's proximate, but it's some -- some species of causation.  And yet, nobody wants this really to be -- neither you nor your adversary nor the Government wants this to be a -- to be based on causation.  Everyone wants to smuggle something else into -- into here -- into this.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Give me an example of a -- of an injury that occurs on the shelf that is not a consequence of operations conducted.  What -- just beachcombers out there, or what?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What are they doing out there?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: How many accountants go to platforms?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But if that -- if that's what Congress meant, then the emphasis should be on is this person one who regularly works on the outer continental shelf.  And the -- this worker, we're told, was on the outer continental shelf 98 percent of the time.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: But Mr. --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But if -- if you had said status or situs, then it seems to me it would have made more sense, given the language of the statute.  We will all have hypotheticals.  We won't have too many, but it's quite common on oil rigs that the employees bring some of the equipment back to the land, clean it, prepare it, and so that they can bring it back to the next -- the next shift on the rig.  And some of this machinery is complicated.  It has springs in it. Suppose that the worker brings the machine back from the rig to the land, to the base of operations that's land-based, and is injured in repairing that machine. Under your view, no coverage?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I think that's quite difficult to square with the "as a result" language because this is a result of the operation.  Let's just say the machine got broken because of the -- of the operations, and there -- and he's fixing it and he's injured.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, the Government and --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: The Government and the Ninth Circuit take care of that by saying that the person has to have -- the injured employee has to have spent substantial amount of time on the -- on the offshore operations.  So, you could add that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: I thought your brief, your reply brief, said you -- you superimpose a status test.  You have the situs of the injury, and then you superimpose status.  So, your test is not simple state of -- place of injury.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Yes, I agree.  I thought you had a backup argument --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- in your -- in your reply brief.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Would you call status -- if the test is where you spend a substantial amount of time working, is that what you call status?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: You -- but you call that status?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I'm sorry.  How does that -- how does that provide you situs on the adjacent waters?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I see.  So, you're saying you don't even -- you're not going --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So, how do you get to the water above the shelf?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Instead of saying they're part of the shelf?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I think the issue that Justice Kennedy was alluding to was the example the Ninth Circuit used:  A pitcher on the mound throws a baseball and hits the batter.  The situs is not the mound, but the injury has occurred as a result of pitching.  And so, he's coming up with examples, and I think that's what the Ninth Circuit was saying when it was creating the test of a substantial nexus between the operation and the injury.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: And that's the part of your -- of your definition that gives no credence to that possibility.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: You may be arguing that as a factual matter what this man was doing on land was not a substantial nexus.  That's a different issue than providing a test that limits injury to an operation solely on the shelf.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Well, you're not -- you don't want a but-for test.  Or do you?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: All right.  You don't want a proximate cause test.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Give me your definition of causation now.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: This is a new version of proximate cause, so --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Mr. Clement, I don't really understand proximate cause as applied to a -- a statute that provides for automatic liability rather than liability for negligence.  To say that it's a proximate cause of a particular act of negligence is one thing, and we have a whole body of law that gives guidance for that.  But do you know of any other situation where we talk of proximate cause, something proximately caused by operations?  Not by a particular act of negligence or -- I don't know how to apply proximate cause to an operation.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. Clement, if your position is right, then we have a worker who most of the time is doing work on a platform, and he will be covered or not depending on whether the injury occurred on the shelf or on the land.  So, it's -- the other view is to say what this person does most of the time is what counts.  Then this worker would always be covered by OCSLA.  And if you take your view, then one will be covered by OCSLA; another one who is doing the same job is covered by a State -- a State -- you have a variety of State workers' compensation laws as opposed to a uniform law governing workers of this kind.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: That's what brings me -- I'm looking at petition appendix 96, 903(a) that you referred us to.  I wasn't quite sure of your argument with respect to this statute.  This statute is a situs-based statute.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But since Congress didn't follow this model in the -- in subsection (b) that we're looking for and used "as a result," why doesn't that show that Congress meant something different?  I didn't hear your argument on that point.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I don't see, in other words, how 903 doesn't hurt you more than it helps you.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But it doesn't; it talks about where the injury occurs, and that's not what -- and that's not what (b) says.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. Clement, may I go back to -- you referred to Herb's Welding, but that was a case -- it was a claim under the Longshore Act, not an OCSLA claim, and the Court said it was expressing no opinion on whether 1332(b) covered the injury.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But Congress also did not adopt the proposal, the specific proposal to confine OCSLA to situations in which State workers' compensation was unavailable.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What reason did they have to use the terminology "as a result of" instead of simply saying that this Act applies only with regard to injuries on the platform, which is what other statutes did say?  I mean, other statutes had a geographical requirement.  What a strange way to say it, "as a result of operations."

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: But, Mr. Clement, you are asking us to just ignore six words in this statute, right?  You read the statute as any injury occurring on the outer continental shelf, when in fact the statute says "any injury occurring as the result of operations conducted on the outer continental shelf."  And you give a variety of arguments in your brief about what those six words are supposed to do.  They're supposed to cover latent injuries.  They're supposed to make sure that the statute only covers things that happen in the scope of your employment. But your friends come back and say the statute did all those things anyway.  These six words would serve no function under your theory.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: But this goes back to Justice Ginsburg's question.  She asked you how many accountants are there on the shelf?  One can't really imagine that Congress is writing this -- this statute, and drafting those six words in order to make sure that an accountant who goes out to the outer continental shelf isn't covered.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr. Clement. Mr. Palmore.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Mr. Palmore --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, but it's a little -- it's a little different when you're talking about a labor practice and an activity that results in an injury.  Labor practice by its terms is going to have applicability to a particular location.  So, you would expect them to use that type of language.  It doesn't carry the same negative implication you're suggesting under 1333(b).

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Suppose the facts of this case were changed a little bit so that the Respondent, instead of spending 98 percent of his time on an oil rig doing things that he did there, actually spent only 20 percent of his time there, and he spent 80 percent of his time on land doing what he was supposed to be doing at the time of the accident.  This particular operation produced so much scrap metal, he had to spend 80 percent of his time going around with a forklift gathering it up.  Now, would this case come out the same way then?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Then how does that -- I don't see how you get this result out of the statutory language, because the causal connection between the operations on the shelf and the accident are precisely the same in the two situations.  Whether he spends 98 percent of his time on the rig or 2 percent of his time on the rig, that makes no difference whatsoever in the causal relationship.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: The trouble with that is that's not what it says.  It says "as a result of operations."

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And I don't -- you know, I would think he doesn't even have to be an employee, does he?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Mr. Palmore, you're asking us to look at the relationship between the employment and the shelf activities, and the statute asks us to look at the relationship between the injury and the shelf activities.  And those may be two different things and seemingly are two different things in the hypothetical that Justice Alito gave you.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: The backup positions may be better than the primary positions in this case, you know?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What is the backup position that's so much better here?  What is it? (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Well, the trouble is that I have no idea what that means.  Now, they have the example of an accountant on land who spends all of his time doing accounting work for the -- for the oil rig. Why isn't there a substantial connection there?  Were it not for the operations on the oil rig, this guy would be out of work or he'd be doing something completely different.  I don't understand that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: A substantial nexus is just right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Do you accept your adversary's position that whatever causal -- you have to, given your status test.  Where are you drawing your status test from?  Meaning, obviously it's not from the language.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: You're not -- I would have just thought you would have taken it out of (b) subdivision (2), the term "employer," almost the obverse, means an employer -- means an employer any of whose employees are employed in such operations.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: What if -- but what if that exposure is not pertinent to what they're doing? Let's take the same individual, 98 percent of the time on the rig and 2 percent on land.  An emergency comes up.  They need a new part, and they say:  Here, go -- you know, go drive to Reno where they have a new part and bring it back.  And he skids off the road and is injured.  Is he really covered by the Offshore Act?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, so, he's subject -- he's injured by, you know, a hazard on the road to Reno.  He's -- I don't know how many miles that is from the offshore, and yet he's still covered by the Offshore Act?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Yes, but --but Mr. Clement says that -- and we can argue about whether the language does it or not, but the system he comes up with, he says, creates a very sensible division.  You're either under the Longshore Act or you're under this Act.  And -- whereas, in your situation, you can be under both, can't you?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, why does that make any sense?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Which one prevails when they both apply?  Are there any differences between the two?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I think the question is, is there any difference between the two?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, why wouldn't they have been -- I mean, as I understand it, if a person of a certain set -- and it's the same set in both, virtually, the same set of people -- where they're injured on navigable waters or piers and docks and so forth, it's the Longshore Act.  And if you're on the platform, it's this Act, so far.  And the benefits are the same.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Okay.  So, the only thing that extending this does, I think he says, is imagine a person who worked on a platform goes to get some platform bits repaired miles from the sea.  Now, that person would not be covered by Longshore Act, would he?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: No.  And he would be covered by this, if they're right, but not if Clement is right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Okay.  So, he's saying what point was there for Congress to do that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Let me give you an example. It might help.  A longshoreman is working on a dock. Someone tells him:  There is a winch here that's broken; take it to the plant to have it repaired, which is 100 miles inland.  He does it, and he's hurt at the plant.  He is not covered, correct?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Correct.  Yes, that's right.  So, he's not covered.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But if the same thing happens on the platform, under your theory he is covered.  Now, your opponent is asking a reasonable question.  That seems to be about the only difference that he can think of, whether it's the one Act or the other, and why would Congress have done that?  That's his question, and I'd like to hear the answer.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So, your answer is basically there are many statutes like this, they all have some kind of OCSLA-type requirement, it's the Longshore Act that was rather stingy, and we don't know why.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Why?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Because of the workmen's compensation?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Would the -- would worker who went to the factory be covered by State workmen's comp?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I'm sorry; I don't understand the answer.  So, he's covered by both?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Oh.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: When you're covered by both the Longshore Act and State workmens' comp, can you proceed under either one?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You can't get --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But you think you can proceed under the State law if you choose.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Does -- do we owe -- do the courts give some deference to the director's position?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Please.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Mr. Frederick.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I don't think that's an anomaly.  I mean, you know, if it's a floating platform, it's a vessel.  The difference between a vessel and a dock.  Is it an anomaly that you're covered under the Longshore Act if you're injured on a dock, which is fixed, but you are not -- you're covered under the Jones Act instead if you're on a vessel, which is not fixed?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That doesn't seem to me like an anomaly at all.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: How many floating platforms are there, anyway?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: MR. FREDERICK:

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: MR. FREDERICK: And they're covered by the Yes.  That's correct. They should be; they're But the point is that they get a Jones Act remedy if they happen to be injured on land.  So, Mr. Chief Justice, under your hypothetical, if the Jones Act seaman is driving to Reno and there's an accident, he's covered under the Jones Act and gets to have a Jones Act remedy, notwithstanding that the injury has nothing to do with his service on the vessel itself.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You're -- you are not proposing to eliminate that anomaly?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You're saying wherever you are injured, so long as you're on a platform, you're covered.  I don't think so.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So, you still have an anomaly.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Sometimes it will be covered; sometimes it won't be covered.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Is there any injury on land in the course of employment that would not be covered by OCSLA where we have a worker of this kind that -- who spends 98 percent of his time on the outer continental shelf -- the injury, however, is on land? Is there any case where such a worker who predominantly works on the outer continental shelf would not be covered by OCSLA in your view?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: So, then what you're really saying is -- it's not your test, but really the Government's saying we look to see, is this person dominantly working on the outer continental shelf?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So, if you work only 20 percent of your time for this -- this drilling company on -- on the -- on the platform, but it so happens that you are injured on the platform, you know, a bolt comes off and strikes you, you're not covered?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, then -- then you're not applying the -- the employment test.  I mean, you either are or you are not.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Heads, I win; tails, you lose, right?  We -- we have a situs-of-the-injury test when you have less than your -- a majority of your work on the platform, but we don't have a situs test when the majority is on the platform.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: this statute?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Was it the Longshore Act? I thought -- I thought it was the Jones Act that they were covered in the helicopter.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, I mean, both positions --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Both positions, Mr. Frederick, are vulnerable to particular hypotheticals. You have imprecision on what it means to spend most of your time on the -- on the shelf, and they have their own problems.  And what do you do with somebody who's -- 3 months he's on the shelf, and then 3 months he's back -- back on land 3 months?  Does it depend when the injury occurs, whether it's when he's on the land part of his job or on the shelf part?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, that's -- I've given you all the totality.  He's working for 3 months, and then he's -- you know, it's seasonal or something, and 3 months he's on -- on the land.  That is the totality of the circumstances.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Why?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Where -- how do you know it's the kind of person?  I thought your line was whether or not he spends most of his time on the shelf or most of his time somewhere else.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thirty percent is the line?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, I know, but we'd like to have a test that we apply to your situation, and it's nice to know -- maybe 30 percent, I guess, is as good as any.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: So, suppose, Mr. Frederick, that we find that we can't find your status test in the language of the statute and that what this statute seems to give us is, instead, a causal test and that the cause is whether operations on the outer continental shelf caused the injury in question.  So, what's your best argument for how operations on the shelf caused the injury in this case?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I assume that the Act would also apply under your analysis to a -- an independent contractor, a trucker, who carries this heavy -- this heavy steel to the place where this worker worked on it, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- but he would not have been carrying the steel had it not been for the -- for the operations on the shelf.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I see.  I see.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: He would be covered if -- if -- he were employed by the -- by the firm that operates the platform, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well -- it's just the guy that drives the truck that takes the steel to the place where your client worked on it.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Unless he spent 30 percent of his time on the shelf.  Then he's covered.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Is it 30 percent of his time over his career or that month or in a year?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: You -- you're talking about the Chandris standard that the seaman's relationship to the vessel must be substantial in nature and duration --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: And that's a kind of a vague -- what's substantial?  It's the same problem we have here.  What is the --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Yes.  So, how have courts worked this out?  What is a substantial relation to the vessel?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, that's a real -- obviously, it's a real mishmash, and maybe that's what we're -- we're stuck with.  How does this work as a practical matter?  I assume the -- the companies get insurance to cover their risks here.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Who decides -- I mean, the insurance company will underwrite how many people spend what percentage of time where?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: No -- well, they have to pay higher insurance rates.  To say they're not liable for it I think is a real --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Does it carry over who's an employee from the Longshoreman Act?  Which defines an employee as a maritime worker, and then defines that and has exceptions and so forth, and this has a couple more. That's who the employee is; is that right?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, but you -- I don't mean to get back to it all the time, but it's not -- you have to say that Congress contemplated the person who spent 30 percent of his time on the outer continental shelf.  In terms of us coming up with a test.  Maybe your client is an easy case, where it's 98 percent.  But the test you want us to adopt covers the person who spends 70 percent of his time on land.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Mr. Clement, you have 4 minutes remaining.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But why -- why doesn't Congress know?  Because I think States overwhelmingly would include outer continental shelf workers in their compensation scheme.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: It would make sense to use the Longshore Act because they wanted to have the same level of compensation.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: No.  No, no. They wanted the OCSLA worker to have the same benefits as the longshore worker.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. The case is submitted.
